protocol_name: Long term Cryopreservation of Chloroviruses by Infection of Chlorella
protocol_name_html: Long term Cryopreservation of Chloroviruses by Infection of Chlorella
description: Contact Dr. Steven Wilhelm (wilhelm@utk.edu) or Samantha Coy (srose16@vols.utk.edu) for additional information regarding this protocol.

groups.group_name: The Aquatic Microbial Ecology Research Group - AMERG (The Buchan, Zinser and Wilhelm labs)

status_info: We are still developing and optimizing this protocol...we anticipate publication of the full protocol in the coming months with long term supporting data

components.data: Confirm that the lysate (PBCV-1 in this case) does not contain anything other than the virus that is being used. This can be completed with PCR and gel electrophoresis of known gene markers.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Confirm that the lysate (PBCV-1 in this case) does not contain anything other than the virus that is being used. This can be completed with PCR and gel electrophoresis of known gene markers.

components.data: Perform a plaque assay to determine the plaque forming units (PFU/mL) of the virus to determine the volume required for the desired MOI at which the Chlorella (NC64A) cells will be infected pre-cryopreservation.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Perform a plaque assay to determine the plaque forming units (PFU/mL) of the virus to determine the volume required for the desired MOI at which the Chlorella (NC64A) cells will be infected pre-cryopreservation.

components.data: Grow a stock culture of NC64A for 48 hr under continuous light at 25ºC to ~2*107 cells/mL at the desired volume.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Grow a stock culture of NC64A for 48 hr under continuous light at 25ºC to ~2*107 cells/mL at the desired volume.

components.data:
Make 30% stocks of DMSO, Ethylene glycol, and L-proline diluted in Milli-Q. Combine all three for a final concentration of 10% each in a clean flask. Aliquot desired volume to each cryovial, set on ice.

 

*You want to have a 50:50 ratio of virus to cryoprotectants (CPAs). I use 1 mL PBCV-1+NC64A and 1 mL CPAs in cryovials. You can determine the amount of CPAs needed based on the desired amount of cryopreserved host infected virus samples.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Make 30% stocks of DMSO, Ethylene glycol, and L-proline diluted in Milli-Q. Combine all three for a final concentration of 10% each in a clean flask. Aliquot desired volume to each cryovial, set on ice.

 

*You want to have a 50:50 ratio of virus to cryoprotectants (CPAs). I use 1 mL PBCV-1+NC64A and 1 mL CPAs in cryovials. You can determine the amount of CPAs needed based on the desired amount of cryopreserved host infected virus samples.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 4 of Long-term Cryopreservation of Infected Chlorella with Chloroviruses
source_data.protocol_name: Long term Cryopreservation of Chloroviruses by Infection of Chlorella
source_data.protocol_name_html: Long term Cryopreservation of Chloroviruses by Infection of Chlorella
source_data.annotation: Sterilize cryoprotectants by filtering through a 0.45 um filter.
source_data.thread_text: Sterilize cryoprotectants by filtering through a 0.45 um filter.
source_data.body: Sterilize cryoprotectants by filtering through a 0.45 um filter.

components.data: Infect NC64A with Chlorovirus at a multiplicty of infection (MOI) = ~5.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Infect NC64A with Chlorovirus at a multiplicty of infection (MOI) = ~5.

components.data: Collect samples at the desired time points during the infection cycle in duplicates and add the desired volume of host infected virus to CPAs in cryovials.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Collect samples at the desired time points during the infection cycle in duplicates and add the desired volume of host infected virus to CPAs in cryovials.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 7 of Long-term Cryopreservation of Infected Chlorella with Chloroviruses
source_data.protocol_name: Long term Cryopreservation of Chloroviruses by Infection of Chlorella
source_data.protocol_name_html: Long term Cryopreservation of Chloroviruses by Infection of Chlorella
source_data.annotation: In our hands, collection of a sample at 240 min post-infection shows the greatest recovery of viable cells (and thus viruses) for PBCV-1 post-crypreservation
source_data.thread_text: In our hands, collection of a sample at 240 min post-infection shows the greatest recovery of viable cells (and thus viruses) for PBCV-1 post-crypreservation
source_data.body: In our hands, collection of a sample at 240 min post-infection shows the greatest recovery of viable cells (and thus viruses) for PBCV-1 post-crypreservation

components.data: Transfer cryovials directly to a slow-freeze container, such as Mr. Frosty, filled with isopropanol at -80ºC overnight.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Transfer cryovials directly to a slow-freeze container, such as Mr. Frosty, filled with isopropanol at -80ºC overnight.

components.data: Transfer samples into a -150ºC freezer until the desired treatment period is over.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Transfer samples into a -150ºC freezer until the desired treatment period is over.

components.data: Transfer vials to ice and let thaw slowly.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Transfer vials to ice and let thaw slowly.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 10 of Long-term Cryopreservation of Infected Chlorella with Chloroviruses
source_data.protocol_name: Long term Cryopreservation of Chloroviruses by Infection of Chlorella
source_data.protocol_name_html: Long term Cryopreservation of Chloroviruses by Infection of Chlorella
source_data.annotation: Be aware that the infection cycle will continue once thawed, and if it completes, the number of virus in the sample will dramatically increase. This will make it impossible to determine % viability.
source_data.thread_text: Be aware that the infection cycle will continue once thawed, and if it completes, the number of virus in the sample will dramatically increase. This will make it impossible to determine % viability.
source_data.body: Be aware that the infection cycle will continue once thawed, and if it completes, the number of virus in the sample will dramatically increase. This will make it impossible to determine % viability.

components.data: Resuspend pelleted materials in appropriate buffer, such as PBS buffer, to the same volume that you started with pre-cryopreservation (volume of host infected virus+CPAs).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Resuspend pelleted materials in appropriate buffer, such as PBS buffer, to the same volume that you started with pre-cryopreservation (volume of host infected virus+CPAs).

components.data:
Perform a plaque assay to determine PFU/mL and % viability post-cryopreservation. Calculate the number of viable cells by assuming 100% viability based on the number of cells that were originally infected.

 

Viablity calculations:

(NC64A initial concentration)*(total volume of Chlorovirus infected host)*(MOI) = 

(Total NC64A)/(Chlorovirus initial concentration) = 

total mL Chlorovirus to infect Chlorella

 

(volume of Chlorovirus used)*(Chlorovirus initial concentration) = total Chlorovirus PFU

(volume of Chlorella used)*(Chlorella initial concentration) = total Chlorella cells

Ratio: (total Chlorovirus)/(total Chlorella)

 

(total Chlorovirus)/(total volume of Chlorovirus infected host) = (Amount of Chlorovirus (PFU/mL) in the total volume)/(2) = (PFU/mL)/(Ratio) = PFU/mL for 100% viability
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Perform a plaque assay to determine PFU/mL and % viability post-cryopreservation. Calculate the number of viable cells by assuming 100% viability based on the number of cells that were originally infected.

 

Viablity calculations:

(NC64A initial concentration)*(total volume of Chlorovirus infected host)*(MOI) = 

(Total NC64A)/(Chlorovirus initial concentration) = 

total mL Chlorovirus to infect Chlorella

 

(volume of Chlorovirus used)*(Chlorovirus initial concentration) = total Chlorovirus PFU

(volume of Chlorella used)*(Chlorella initial concentration) = total Chlorella cells

Ratio: (total Chlorovirus)/(total Chlorella)

 

(total Chlorovirus)/(total volume of Chlorovirus infected host) = (Amount of Chlorovirus (PFU/mL) in the total volume)/(2) = (PFU/mL)/(Ratio) = PFU/mL for 100% viability

source_data.protocol_name_html: Long term Cryopreservation of Chloroviruses by Infection of Chlorella
source_data.annotation: I typically see a ~80% viability at the timepoint 240 min post-infection and ~20% viability at the timepoint 180 min post-infection.
source_data.thread_text: I typically see a ~80% viability at the timepoint 240 min post-infection and ~20% viability at the timepoint 180 min post-infection.
source_data.body: I typically see a ~80% viability at the timepoint 240 min post-infection and ~20% viability at the timepoint 180 min post-infection.

components.data: Always use the '1/3 rule'. That is, infect enough host so that 1/3 of the sample volume (PBCV-1 + NC64A) is left after all of the samples have been collected and aliquoted with CPAs.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Always use the '1/3 rule'. That is, infect enough host so that 1/3 of the sample volume (PBCV-1 + NC64A) is left after all of the samples have been collected and aliquoted with CPAs.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 4 of Long-term Cryopreservation of Infected Chlorella with Chloroviruses
source_data.protocol_name: Long term Cryopreservation of Chloroviruses by Infection of Chlorella
source_data.protocol_name_html: Long term Cryopreservation of Chloroviruses by Infection of Chlorella
source_data.annotation: The 1/3 rule is used to have extra biomass leftover incase you need extra for sampling errors, and to prevent bottle effects in your final samples.
source_data.thread_text: The 1/3 rule is used to have extra biomass leftover incase you need extra for sampling errors, and to prevent bottle effects in your final samples.
source_data.body: The 1/3 rule is used to have extra biomass leftover incase you need extra for sampling errors, and to prevent bottle effects in your final samples.
